Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Injury.Injury_with_annotation: 7 people in one California home were hospitalized for carbon monoxide poisoning from a lantern.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: The January 2008 North American storm complex was a powerful Pacific extratropical cyclone that affected a large portion of North America, primarily stretching from western British Columbia to near the Tijuana, Mexico area, starting on January 3, 2008.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: The storms were responsible for the death of at least 12 people across three states... At least 12 people were killed including two in California, eight in Utah and two in Oregon due to falling branches or trees, traffic accidents, and flooding... Eight of the fatalities were caused by the rollover of a charter bus in southeastern Utah... At least 16 fatalities1 missing [citation needed]

Time_with_Annotation:
Formed: December 29, 2007 (2nd storm formed)
Dissipated: January 22, 2008 (3rd storm dissipated)[1]

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Insured_Da.Insured_Damage_Assessment_with_annotatio: California Governor Arnold Schwarzenegger also declared a state of emergency for three counties while Oregon Governor Ted Kulongoski declared a state of emergency for Umatilla County due to wind damage.

Nevada Governor Jim Gibbons declared a state of emergency for Lyon County. The Federal Emergency Management Agency was called in for emergency assistance and distribution of food and water. Bank firm Wells Fargo opened an account to collect donations for the residents of Fernley.

Total_Summary_Displacement.Total_Displacement_Annotation: At least 3000 people were rescued by helicopter from rooftops of flooded homes while cold temperatures hindered rescue efforts.

Location_with_Annotation.Western British Columbia: The January 2008 North American storm complex was a powerful Pacific extratropical cyclone that affected a large portion of North America, primarily stretching from western British Columbia to near the Tijuana, Mexico area, starting on January 3, 2008.
Location_with_Annotation.Tijuana, Mexico: The January 2008 North American storm complex was a powerful Pacific extratropical cyclone that affected a large portion of North America, primarily stretching from western British Columbia to near the Tijuana, Mexico area, starting on January 3, 2008.
Location_with_Annotation.California: The system was responsible for flooding rains across many areas in California along with very strong winds locally exceeding hurricane force strength as well as heavy mountain snows across the Cascade and Sierra Nevada mountain chains as well as those in Idaho, Utah and Colorado.
Location_with_Annotation.Cascade and Sierra Nevada mountain chain: The system was responsible for flooding rains across many areas in California along with very strong winds locally exceeding hurricane force strength as well as heavy mountain snows across the Cascade and Sierra Nevada mountain chains as well as those in Idaho, Utah and Colorado.
Location_with_Annotation.Idaho: The system was responsible for flooding rains across many areas in California along with very strong winds locally exceeding hurricane force strength as well as heavy mountain snows across the Cascade and Sierra Nevada mountain chains as well as those in Idaho, Utah and Colorado.
Location_with_Annotation.Utah: The system was responsible for flooding rains across many areas in California along with very strong winds locally exceeding hurricane force strength as well as heavy mountain snows across the Cascade and Sierra Nevada mountain chains as well as those in Idaho, Utah and Colorado.
Location_with_Annotation.Colorado: The system was responsible for flooding rains across many areas in California along with very strong winds locally exceeding hurricane force strength as well as heavy mountain snows across the Cascade and Sierra Nevada mountain chains as well as those in Idaho, Utah and Colorado.
Location_with_Annotation.Oregon: From January 4 to 5, general rainfall from the superstorm in the West Coast was around 2 inches (51 mm) of rain in Oregon and Utah, while nearly 4 inches (100 mm) fell over parts of Nevada and as much as 10 inches (250 mm) in parts of California.
Location_with_Annotation.Nevada: From January 4 to 5, general rainfall from the superstorm in the West Coast was around 2 inches (51 mm) of rain in Oregon and Utah, while nearly 4 inches (100 mm) fell over parts of Nevada and as much as 10 inches (250 mm) in parts of California.
Location_with_Annotation.Washington State: Waves were reported as high as 37.7 feet (11.5 m) offshore Washington State.
Location_with_Annotation.Western Canada: Later on the same day, the 3rd storm began to interact with the 1st storm, which was situated over northwestern Canada, weakening that system.
Location_with_Annotation.Hudson Bay: Soon afterwards, a few clumps of the mass of moisture organized into separate storm systems, while the dominant low over Canada stalled just southwest of Hudson Bay.
Location_with_Annotation.Great Lakes region: On January 9, the low pressure center over the Great Lakes region became the dominant low of the storm complex.
Location_with_Annotation.Atlantic Canada: On January 10, the low west of Hudson Bay dissipated, while the main storm complex began to exit Atlantic Canada.
Location_with_Annotation.Labrador Sea: On January 11, the storm entered Labrador Sea, and stalled for several hours, before continuing to move northeastward.
Location_with_Annotation.Greenland: On January 12, the system reorganized to the southeast of Greenland, and was assigned the name Ilse by the Free University of Berlin.
Location_with_Annotation.Norwegian Sea: On January 14, Windstorm Ilse intensified to 980 millibars (29 inHg) and impacted the United Kingdom and parts of Western Europe, before entering the Norwegian Sea on January 15.
Location_with_Annotation.San Francisco: Highways from Sacramento to San Francisco were closed by debris.
Location_with_Annotation.Eastern California: Flights departing from San Francisco were grounded, while over 100 miles (160 km) of Interstate 80 was shut down in eastern California and western Nevada due to poor visibility and a 17-vehicle pile-up.
Location_with_Annotation.Western Nevada: Flights departing from San Francisco were grounded, while over 100 miles (160 km) of Interstate 80 was shut down in eastern California and western Nevada due to poor visibility and a 17-vehicle pile-up.
Location_with_Annotation.Sacramento: Highways from Sacramento to San Francisco were closed by debris.
Location_with_Annotation.Orange County: Mandatory evacuations were ordered in Orange County in Southern California.
Location_with_Annotation.Reno, Nevada: On January 5, a canal levee ruptured near Reno, Nevada and flooded some 800 residences.
Location_with_Annotation.Lyon County: Nevada Governor Jim Gibbons declared a state of emergency for Lyon County.
Location_with_Annotation.Fernley: Bank firm Wells Fargo opened an account to collect donations for the residents of Fernley.
Location_with_Annotation.Umatilla County: Oregon Governor Ted Kulongoski declared a state of emergency for Umatilla County due to wind damage.
Location_with_Annotation.San Bernardino Mountains: A hiker went missing in the San Bernardino Mountains.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Economic_D.Economic_Damage_Assessment_with_annotati: Strong winds knocked power lines down causing power outages for 1.2 million Californians,[7] while several outages were reported in Washington and Oregon.[34] About 500 miles (800 km) of California power lines were damaged by the storm.[35]
On January 5, a canal levee ruptured near Reno, Nevada and flooded some 800 residences.[37]
Nevada Governor Jim Gibbons declared a state of emergency for Lyon County.
Oregon Governor Ted Kulongoski declared a state of emergency for Umatilla County due to wind damage.

Perils_Assessment_With_Annotation.Wind: The system was responsible for flooding rains across many areas in California along with very strong winds locally exceeding hurricane force strength as well as heavy mountain snows across the Cascade and Sierra Nevada mountain chains as well as those in Idaho, Utah and Colorado.
Perils_Assessment_With_Annotation.Rainfall: The system was responsible for flooding rains across many areas in California along with very strong winds locally exceeding hurricane force strength as well as heavy mountain snows across the Cascade and Sierra Nevada mountain chains as well as those in Idaho, Utah and Colorado.
Perils_Assessment_With_Annotation.Flood: On January 5, a canal levee ruptured near Reno, Nevada and flooded some 800 residences.
Perils_Assessment_With_Annotation.Landslide: The storm closed ski resorts, toppled trees, and created mudslides.
Perils_Assessment_With_Annotation.Blizzard: The system was responsible for flooding rains across many areas in California along with very strong winds locally exceeding hurricane force strength as well as heavy mountain snows across the Cascade and Sierra Nevada mountain chains as well as those in Idaho, Utah and Colorado.
Perils_Assessment_With_Annotation.Tornado: As the storm complex moved westward on January 7, the instability in the air triggered a rare January tornado outbreak, spawning 55 tornadoes over the course of 2 days, resulting in the deaths of 4 more people.
